div3.head:
[written for the Richmond Dispatch.]
war to the death!
by Seniran.

lg.l: Now fling the broad-barred banner in triumph to the breeze,
And the al tyrant Fear and temble when he sees;
Now let our glad rejoicings Up to the skies ascend,
And let us to the conflict With a bolder courage bend.
He comes!--the war-scarred here, He comes with laurels crowned;
We know our leader's prowess, And our souls with joy rebound.
If he leads us we will battle With opposition, to the knife,
And his clarion voice shall nerve us, And shall steel us for the strife.
Mid the death and devastation, Mid the murderous shot and shell,
If he's there we'll do our duty, And we'll do our duty well;
In the face of bursting scaraphell, Mid the howling storm of ball,
We will fight — aye, fight forever. For our country, for our all!
Then let our new born ensign Bid distance to the foe,
And beneath it we will gladly O'er his very ramparts go;
No matter it we're crippled, Or are number d with the slain.
Their'll be plenty proud Southrons Glad to swell the tanks again.
Let us strike, and strike right nobly, For our altars and our fires,
For our children's generation, For our families and sires.
Oh! let the thought eu us, Let us die upon the field,
Ere we to the nated tyrant Liberty like ours yield.

div3.head: The Cotton-Spinning interest of England.
div3.p: The following remarks on the interesting subjects suggested in the title of this article, are from the pen of a Southern gentleman who is especially well qualified to write upon them:

q.p:
"Few of your readers are aware of the immense loss of Southern wealth incident to the transportation of the cotton crop to Europe in the present 'raw' or 'lint' form.
It is sent forward as a colonial product to England, where it is spun into yarn (or thread,) and then re-exported to the continent of Europe, to India, China, and South American, in immense quantities, and with a corresponding enhancement in value.
It is the cotton but which makes valuable the coal and front of Great Britain.
The great industry of England is the cotton spinning industry, and in this branch of manufacturing the United States are yet destined to supplant all rivals

"Georgia, North Carolina, Virginia, and Maryland, are capable of becoming the cotton- spinners of the world and we may yet live to see the day when a bale-of-lint' cotton offered for export to a foreign or coastwise port, will be as great a curiosity as is now a bale of cotton in the seed.
It the American cotton crop were shipped in the shape of yarn or thread, it would make a saving to our national wealth in the items of waste and transportation alone of 25 per cent on the total crop, or say fifty millions of dollars — a sum sufficient to construct the Pacific Railroad, and cut a ship canal across Florida.
The Atlantic Southern States, from Georgia to Maryland, would receive an addition to their wealth, through the demand for coal, and iron, and water power, and the consequent activity to the full and railway interest. "The difference between the American cotton crop in the 'lint' and in the 'thread' is the difference between a crop of 'low ordinary' and 'strictly good middling,' or 2½ to 3 cents a pound.
For some very interesting data on this subject we refer the reader to a calculation made by Mr. G. G. Henry, of Mobile.
Waile Mr. Henry's preliminary data are very important, we have always found that his plan of making each cotton-grower or planter also a cotton spinner would be difficult of accomplishment.
But, like all great improvements, original ideas are seized by practical minds and turned into account.
The idea of shipping the American cotton crop in the form of 'yarn' or 'thread' is now receiving the earnest attention of practical men in England, Germany and America.
It is a great measure, and one possessing a vast amount of interesting detail, which we may take occasion hereafter to make the subject of special attention in this paper.
Everything calculated to develop American industry possesses an interest for us, and we are always particularly gratified when we see the Southern States turning their attention to the immense resources so lavishly bestowed upon them by the bountiful hand of Nature.
We therefore wish the direct trade movement of the South that measure of success to which every fair commercial enterprise is entitled.
If the cotton crop can be spun into thread by the Atlantic Southern States, it furnishes another bond of unity between the States of the South, and is another stride in power taken by 'King Cotton' "In this connection we think it proper to allude to the fact, that the Surat or Indian cottons are valueless except when used with the American staple.
By yielding the monopoly of spinning up our crop to England, we have enabled her gradually to introduce the Surat cotton into the continental markets, until now we find that over seven hundred thousand bales of Surats are placed anually in Europe.
Every bale of 'India Surat' cotton which England succeeds in forcing into consumption through the aid of our good stapled cottons, and by having the exclusive monopoly of 'spinning' for the world, displaces a bale of our lower or 'inferior' grades.
The consequence of this policy is now manifest at Liverpool.
The lower grades of American cottons are not asked for, the English spinners having worked in the India cotton, and nearly six hundred thousand bales are in Europe without buyers, and depreciating daily in value.
Does any one doubt that if these six hundred thousand bales had been spun into thread in America they would have been preferred by the German, Swiss, or French weaver to the flimsy 'Surat' thread they are forced to take from England?
This is an exceedingly important matter, and we trust that it will be carefully looked after, and successfully promoted, to the end that we may become the spinners of our own cotton crop, letting the world buy the 'thread' from us."

div3.head:
Toby's experience with a breech-loading rifle.
[from the Oxford (Miss.) Intelligencer.]
div3.p:
Toby is a high private in the First Regiment of the Mississippi army.
His company is armed with breech-loading Maynard rifles, "warranted to shoot twelve times a minute, and carry a ball effectually 1,600 yards." Men who fought at Montrey and Buena Vista, call the new fangled thing a "pop gun." To lost its efficacy, Toby's Captain told the men they must "try their guns." In obedience to command, Toby procured the necessary munnidone of war and started with his "pop gun" for the woods.
Saw a squirrel up a very high tree — took aim — fired.
Effects of shot immediate and wonderful.
Tree effectually stripped, and nothing of the squirrel to be found except three broken hairs "Pop gun" rose in value equal to a four pounder.
But Toby wouldn't shoot towards any more trees — afraid of being arrested for cutting down other people's timber.
Walked a mile and a quarter to get sight of a hill.
By aid of a small telescope saw a hill in the distance; saw large rock on hill; put in a big load; shut both eyes — fired.
As soon as breath returned opened both eyes; could she, just could, but couldn't hear; at least couldn't distinguish any sounds; tho't Niagara bad broke loose or all outdoors gone to drum beating.
Determined to see if shot hit Borrowed horse and started towards bill — After traveling two days and nights reached placed; saw setting sun shining through hill Knew right away that was where his shot hit Went closer — stumbled over rocky fragments scattered for a half mile in line of bullet.--Come to a hole — knew the builet hit there, because saw lead on the edges — walked through saw teamster on the other side "indulging in profane language" because lightning had killed his team.
Looked as finger directed — saw six dead oxen in line with hole through mountain; knew that was the bullet's work, but didn't say so to angry teamster.
Thought best to be leaving, in consequence didn't explore path of bullet any further; therefore don't know where it stopped; don't know whether it stopped at all; in fact, rather think it didn't. Mounted horse; rode back through the hole made by the bullet; but never told Captain a word about it; to tell the truth, was rather afraid he'd think it a hoax, "It's a right big story boys," said Toby, in conclusion, "but it's true, sure as shooting.
Nothing to do with the Maynard rifle but load her up, turn her North, and pull trigger; It twenty of them don't clean out all Yankeedom, then I'm a liar, that's all."

div3.head: To make Rhubare Wine.
div3.p: --To one gallon of water add four pounds of ripe rhubarb, thoroughly bruised; let it stand in the tub four days; stir it frequently, then strain it; to one gallon of liquor put four pounds of good coffee sugar, the juice of one and the peel of one-half a lemon; to every ten gallons, one ounce of dinglass and one pint of brandy; put it in a cask; after the fermentation is over bung it tight; let it stand one year or more, then bottle it for use. If kept three or four years it will sparkle like champague.

div3.head: Doctors in the field.
div3.p: --Now in the time for the 1,000 doctors in Georgia, who have made application for office in the Confederate Army, to be received and duly commissioned as high privates. All doctors who are veritable M. D.'s, wishing to join the Doctors' Regiment of Georgia, can do so by addressing A. A. Terhune, M. D., Kingston, or A. G. Thomas, M. D., Secretary Medical Association of Georgia, at Atlanta.--Atlanta Confederacy.
